Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Reinforcement of isolation between parasite host races
Award.AbstractNarration:
A long-standing debate in evolutionary biology is how reproductive barriers among species can arise in the absence of geographic obstacles. New parasite species can often form following infection of a novel host species if barriers to successful reproduction between parasites on the two species exist. This project combines observational, experimental, and genomic studies of a native parasitic plant, desert mistletoe, to address this question. While showing the same epidemiological patterns as many other parasites, parasitic plants allow for direct tests of hypotheses concerning the evolution of barriers to mating in diverging parasite lineages that would be infeasible in other systems. This research will help elucidate the poorly understood ecological mechanisms that promote parasite speciation and adaptation to novel hosts. The potential for studying parallel evolution of parasites undergoing ongoing diversification provides a unique opportunity to study the genomics of species interactions. Additionally, the researchers will disseminate the results to a broad audience through collaborations with local outreach groups interested in native plants and will contribute to the training of graduate and undergraduate students.

This work will test established theory about the relative roles of pre-zygotic and post-zygotic isolation mechanisms in sympatry and allopatry using two host races of a native aerial hemiparasite of plants, Phoradendron californicum (Viscaceae), across their overlapping ranges. Populations of the host races infecting catclaw acacia (Senegalia greggii ) and velvet mesquite (Prosopis velutina) in sympatry (locally interspersed) and allopatry (> 3 km from nearest infected host of other species) will be studied at multiple sites across Arizona. The researchers will conduct selection gradient analyses for flowering time across these populations to test if selection for divergent flowering times (a pre-zygotic isolation mechanism) between the host races is stronger in sympatry than in allopatry. Additionally, the researchers will perform hand-pollination experiments to quantify the cost of mating between host races and the strength of late-acting barriers to gene flow. Finally, population genomic analyses of mistletoes from these host races using RAD sequencing will reveal whether host races are the result of a single host-switching event or repeated, parallel divergence and reinforcement across the range. The researchers will further use the sequence data to investigate the genomic signature of host race formation and adaptation to host species in this parasitic plant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Parasites are perhaps the most diverse and successful organisms on Earth. However, scientific understanding of the processes by which parasites diversify and gain the ability to infect new hosts is incomplete. Different host species will differ in important physical and ecological characteristics; therefore, parasites may need to possess host species specific traits to be successful when infecting different host species. When genetically-encoded traits that predict success on one host species decrease the chance of survival or reproduction on another host, the parasite populations will often diverge genetically in association with host species. When those parasites live in habitats where those different hosts are present together, the genetic divergence between host-associated parasite populations can only be maintained if there are mechanisms to prevent parasites from reproducing with individuals with the “wrong” traits or from being transmitted to the “wrong” host species. We use desert mistletoe, a native parasitic plant that infects desert legume trees, as a model system to study these processes. We use this system because it shows the same patterns as many other vector-transmitted parasites of interest, and its infections are readily studied and followed over time in the field.

 

A major question of the study was whether reproductive traits differ among mistletoes infecting different host species in ways that could contribute to reproductive isolation. We find that this is the case. In particular, mistletoes differ in flowering time by host species such that they are unlikely to mate with individuals from a different host species. The differences in flowering time by host are also greater when the different host species are growing within the same geographic area than when they grow in different locations. This pattern based on geography is expected when mating between individuals on different hosts would be costly to the parasite offspring. In addition to differences in flowering time, we find that mistletoes on different hosts also differ in the size of their flowers, number of pollen grains they produce, and amount of nectar they produce. These differences relate to the pollinators that they attract, which differ in number and species identity according to the host species that the mistletoe infections. These differences should also contribute to maintaining genetically distinct host-associated populations.

 

Additionally, we asked whether genetically distinct host-associated populations of desert mistletoe exist across the geographic range of the species. Preliminary results support the existence of two divergent host-associated populations. One population infects mesquite tree species, and the other infects a variety of other trees, including acacias, desert ironwood, and palo verdes. In addition to these distinct host-associated races, we see geographic patterns in the population genetic structure of the populations with the northernmost populations exhibiting genetic differences from southernmost populations. Although upcoming data will provide more clarity on these patterns, the results of this portion of our work are already prompting testable hypotheses for how genetically distinct populations of parasites arise and spread across the landscape.

 

The scientific contributions of the work were in part possible because of the research experiences gained by undergraduate and high school student participation. Six students were mentored as part of this project, which provided them with some of their first experiences with scientific research. This mentorship process also represented a professional development opportunity for the graduate student co-PI who will use the skills learned in future leadership roles.

 

The results of this work have been published in both peer-reviewed scientific journals and newsletters for the members of local non-profit organizations. Similarly, we have presented this work both at national scientific conferences and at local, public venues for those interested in the importance of research on parasites and native plants.
